UPGRADE OF HIGH DENSITY POLYETHYLENE PYROLYSIS STEAM USING ALUMINOSILICATE CATALYSIS
Kamilla Paes Perez October , 202 1
Advisor: Claudio Jos√© de Ara√∫jo Mota Program: Biofuels and Petrochemical Engineering

The disposal of post -consumer plastic constitutes a global problem that has become more serious in recent years. In this context, c hemical recycling emerges as a possible solution to this problem . Among the available alternatives , pyrolysis has shown to be promising. However, some challenges must yet be overcome, such as the quality of pyrolysis products. In this sense , the use of catalyst can constitute a good alternative. In the present work, three catalysts, a commercial FCC catalyst containing zeolite Y, a commercial catalyst containing ZSM -5 and a catalyst synthesized in the laboratory, Al -MCM41, were used to perform the catalytic pyrolysis of HDPE through thermogravimetric techniques . The effect of catalysts at the beginning of the reaction was evaluated and it was observed that acidity and specific surface area are important parameters to increase the activity of a catalyst. For the commercial FCC catalyst containing zeolite Y, the effect of the catalyst:charge ratio was also evaluated, indicating that the increase of the catalyst amount can lead to reduction of the pyrolysis temperature at the beginning of the reaction . A fixed bed pyrolysis test was also carried out , indicat ing that the catalyst shifts the heavy liquid products (waxes) to wards lighter fractions in the range of C1 -C12. Furthermore, the catalyst promoted the production of larger amounts of isoparaffins and aromatics, according to the carbocationic mechanism of catalyti c cracking.

AP√äNDICE II
UPGRADE OF HIGH DENSITY POLYETHYLENE PYROLYSIS STEAM USING ALUMINOSILICATE CATALYSIS

Kamilla P. Perez1; Jos√© C. C. S. Pinto 1,3; Cl√°udio J. A. Mota 1,2 1 Universidade Federal do Rio de Janeiro, Escola de Qu√≠mica. Av Athos da Silveira Ramos 149, CT Bl E, 2 1949 -909 Rio de Janeiro, Brazil 2 Universidade Federal do Rio de Janeiro, Instituto de Qu√≠mica. Av Athos da Silveira Ramos 149, CT Bl A, 21949 -909 Rio de Janeiro, Brazil 3 Universidade Federal do Rio de Janeiro, COPPE. Rua Moniz Arag√£o N¬∫ 360, CT Bl I, 21941-972 Rio de Janeiro, Brazil
Corresponding authors: Claudio J. A. Mota E-mail: cmota@iq.ufrj.br
Abstract

The performance of t hree acid catalysts based on aluminosilicates were evaluated in the catalytic cracking of virgin high density polyethylene. The materials were characterized by several techniques including XRD, XRF , BET, Acidity and TGA , seeking to correlate the characterization data with the catalytic performance . In addition, a fixed bed catalyst HDPE pyrolysis test was carried out to evaluate the yield and composition of the fractions obtained. It was noted that acidity and surface area are important parameters to increase the activity. Moreover, the pyrolysis test indicates the effect of the catalyst with Y zeolite directing the heavy liquid products (waxes) to lighter fractions in the range of C1 -C12.
Keywords: Catalyst, HDPE, Pyrolysis, Plastic
INTRODUCTION

The increase in production and incorrect or inefficient plastics disposal has aroused the interest of many researchers in the development of chemical recycling techniques, aiming to reinsert plastic waste into the production chain . Among the methods of chemical recycling, pyrolysis stands out as a promising technology (MIANDAD et al., 2017).

Pyrolysis is the process of cracking long -chain polymer molecules into smaller and less complex molecules. It requires temper atures between 300 and 600 ¬∞C and must occur in the absence of oxygen. It is dependent on a number of factors such as temperature, residence time, heating rates and raw material composition. The three main resulting products are oil, gas and coal, which ca n be used in various industrial activities (SHARUDDIN et al., 2016; MIANDAD The pyrolysis can take place in the presence or absence of a catalyst; however, the composition of the products is different. In general , when a catalyst is not used, the cracking of HDPE results in wax. Thus, in order to convert waxes into liquids and reduce the distribution range of the products , acid catalyst s can be applied (MOORTHY RAJENDRAN et al., 2020; SERRANO et The article focuses on the char acterization of the catalysts through the techniques of XRD, XRF, BET, Acidity and TGA and the evaluation of the performance of acid catalysts based on aluminosilicates, in the catalytic cracking of virgin high density polyethylene, to obtain lighter liquid products than those obtained in pyrolysis in the absence of catalyst.
MATERIALS AND METHODS
MATERIALS

High density polyethylene pellets (HDPE) from Braskem were used as the polymer on pyrolysis test and on TGA analysis . Fluidized catalytic cracking catalyst containing zeolite Y (Catalyst 1) from F√°brica Carioca de Catalisadores S.A. were used as a catalyst on fixed bed on pyrolysis test and on TGA analysis . Fluidized catalytic cracking catalyst containing zeolite ZSM -5 (Catalyst 2) from F√°br ica Carioca de Catalisadores S.A . was used as a catalyst on TGA analysis. Mesoporous catalyst, Al -MCM -41 (Catalyst 3) , from Hydrocarbon, Biomass and Catalysis Reactivity Laboratory ‚Äì LARHCO/UFRJ was used as a catalyst on TGA analysis. Butylamine 99% and mo lecular mass of 129.24 g.mol-1 from Vetec. Helium 99% from Air Products Brasil. Nitrogen 99% from Air Products Brasil.
CHARACTERIZATION
FTIR : HDPE f ourier transform infrared spectra were obtained by a Varian 660 -IR FTIR spectrophotometer using KBr pellets in the region of 400 to 4000 cm-1.

XDR: Catalyst 1 and 2 X-ray diffraction spectra was carried out on an Ultima IV - RIGAKU diffractrometer ( Cu Ka radiation, 40 kV and 20 mA) from 2Œ∏ = 2¬∫ to 50¬∞ with a step of 0,02¬∫. Catalyst 3 X-ray diffraction spectra were recorded o n Bruker D2Phaser diffractrometer equipped with a detector Lynxeye with Cu Ka radiation, 30 kV and 10 mA, from 2Œ∏ = 2¬∫ to 10¬∞ with a step of 0,0 2¬∫.
XDF: The X-ray fluorescence analyzes of the catalysts were carried out by F√°brica Carioca de Catalisadores S.A..

TGA: The thermal stability of the synthesized materials was evaluated using a thermogravimetric analyzer (TGA), SHIMADZU TGA -50 model. About 5 mg of sample was used in a platinum pan with a heating rate of 10 ¬∞C/min at 800 ¬∞C under N 2 atmosphere in a flow rate of 50 mL/min. The TGA analyses evaluate the polymer virgin, and polymer and catalysts in a ratio of 1:1.

N2 Adsorption Experiments : The textural properties of the adsorbents were performed by F√°brica Carioca de Catalisadores S.A. . The samples were pretreated at 150 ¬∞C for 10 h under vacuum to remove adsorbed moisture. N 2 adsorption and desorption isotherms at -196 ¬∞C were obtained in a relative pressure range of 0 < P/P 0 < 1. The surface area was calculated by the BET model from adsorption data and pore volume was obtained by the BJH method. Acidity measurements : The acid strength distribution of the catalysts, was measured by tempera ture-programed desorption (TPD) of nbutylamine, using a thermo gravimetric equip equipment to follow the weight loss. About 25 mg of the catalyst were initially pretreated in a straight glass reactor, under flowing helium (40 ml/ min), at 550¬∞C . The temper ature was then set to 150 ¬∞C and the flow of helium was driven to a saturator containing n -butylamine at room temperature for a period of 10 min. The excess of the amine was desorbed, by passing a flow of helium (20 ml/min) over the catalyst bed during 20 m in. The sample was then carefully placed in the thermo gravimetric equipment, Shimadzu TGA -51, and the TPD profile was taken following the weight loss up to 8 00¬∞C, under flowing nitrogen gas (GON√áALVES et al., 2008). CG-MS: For the analysis of the liquid obtained in the pyrolysis, the samples were diluted 1:4 in ethanol and a 1 ¬µL aliquot was injected into the gas chromatograph with a coupled mass spectrometer (Agilent, model 7890A/5975 VL) and equipped with an automatic injector (Agilent, model G45 13A). The carrier gas used was helium, with a split ratio of 1:10. An HP5 - ms capillary column manufactured by Agilent, model 19091S -433, 30 m long, 250 ¬µm internal diameter and 0.25 ¬µm film thickness, whose stationary phase was composed of 5% phenyl - methyl polysiloxane, was used. The compounds were identified according to the NIST (National Institute of Standards and Technology) library.
PYROLYSIS TEST

The pyrolysis reactions were carried out in a tubular quartz reactor coupled with two furnaces, a straigh t condenser and a kitasate. The catalyst was deposited on quartz wool previously inserted in the bottom of the reactor, to support the bed, and then a pot of quartz with the polymer was introduced. Before the reactions, the system was purged for 15 minutes with N 2. The catalyst was also pretreated at 550 ¬∞C for 30 minutes i n N 2 atmosphere. Reaction time and inert gas flow rate were kept constant for all reactions and equal to 30min and 80 ml min‚àí1, respectively. For the pyrolysis reactions with coupled cata lytic bed, the same mass quantities (7.0 g) were used, keeping the load/catalyst ratio 1:1. The pyrolysis were conduced in two temperatures 500¬∞C and 550¬∞C.The gaseous fraction was estimated from the mass balance, assuming that all incoming mass must be equal the outgoing mass, and that the system was perfectly isolated.

RESULTS AND DISCUSSION The FTIR analysis was performed in order to identify the presence of functional groups on the HDPE, as shown in Figure 1. The HDPE FTIR showed the three bands associated with stretching the C -H bond between 2915 and 2848 cm-1; to the angular deformation of this same connection between 1471 and 1463 cm-1 and to the torsion in approximately 730 cm-1, which are characteristic of the HDPE infrared spectrum (TORRES e t al., 2010).

The XR D analysis was performed in order to confirm the structure of the catalysts. The Catalyst 1 XRD, illustrated in Figure 2, showed characteristic peaks of zeolite Y at angles 6, 10, 16, 24, 27, 31 and 32o, presenting a pattern similar to that suggested in the literature (SALAHUDEEN et al., 2014). The XRD diffractogram of the Catalyst 2 is shown in Figure 3. The Catalyst 2 XRD showed characteristic peaks of the ZSM -5 zeolite at angles 8, 9, 23 and 24o (MAGEE et al.,1993). The XRD diffractogram of the Catalyst 3 is shown in Figure 4. The Catalyst 3 XRD exhibit a well -defined peak at an angle of 2.5¬∞ that can be attributed to the line reflection (100), characteristic of the hexagonal structure of Al -MCM -41. In addition, two not very intense and wide peaks at the angles of 3.9 and 4.4o, corresponding to the reflection lines (110) and (200), respectively, confirms the high cryst allinity and the ordered hexagonal geometry of the pores of the mesoporous materials (LA -SALVIAA et al., 2017).

The thermogravimetric analysis was performed to evaluate the influence of the catalysts on the thermal degradation of HDPE, as shown in Figure 5 . All catalysts showed good effect, reducing the temperature of complete degradation of HDPE. It was possible to observe that Catalyst 3 showed a loss of mass (13%) at the beginning of the reaction between 19 and 95¬∞C, as well as Catalyst 1 which had a loss of mass (4%), not too pronounced, between 49 and 79¬∞C. This initial mass loss did not occur for Catalyst 2. Since t he temperature was low, such mass losses may have been related to water loss . However, this may also be the possible effect of accessibility and surface area, since Catalyst 3 has high surface area and mesoporous. Catalyst 1, in additio n, had larger pores than Catalyst 2, a nd a higher surface area. This is corroborated by the fact that some authors point out that cracking starts on the external surface or in the mouth of the pores and, subsequently, these initial products degradations are converted into the catalyst through secondary reactions. In addition , higher area will allow more contact between the catalyst and the pyrolysis reagents, resulting in better conversion (SERRANO et al., 2012; CALDEIRA et al., 2017).
Figure 5: Thermogram of Catalyst 1, 2 and 3 with HDPE.

Regarding acidity, comparing zeolitic catalysts (Catalyst 1 and 2), it was observed that it plays an important role. From the results obtained, at temperatures where the mass loss was 5%, as shown in Figure 6, Catalyst 1, with higher acidity, demonstrated a superior effect than Catalyst 2, with lower acidity. On the other hand, when Catalyst 1 was compared with Catalyst 3 it was noticed that, even with a lower acidity, Catalyst 3 proved to be much more efficient than the first one. This can be explained by the fact that although mesoporous materials in general have lower acidity than zeolitic materials, their activity is sometimes offset by highly accessible areas (CALDEIRA et al., 2017). So, acidity most likely plays a seco ndary role when compared to accessibility.

The catalyst effect was remarkable, which converted a considerable portion of the liquid fraction into a gaseous fraction at temperature of 500¬∞C and 5 50¬∞C. Another relevant aspect observed in the pyrolysis tests was the aspect of condensables. In the absence of catalyst, the condensables obtained solidified forming a kind of wax, while in the presence of the catalyst there was no wax formation, just an oil, as shown in Figure 7.

In pyrolysis teste was observed that the increase on temperature did not demonstrate a significant change on the profile of the products . However, the presence of the catalyst directed affect the composition of the liquid products , increasing isoparaffins and aromatics componds, as shown in Figure 8 . This can be explained by the mechanism of catalytic cracking , which occurs through a carbocation mechanism. Carbocation is formed by abstracting a hydride ion from a Lewis acid site to form carben ium ions or by protonating the hydrocarbon at Br√∂nsted acid sites, generating carbanion ions. Once these carbocations are forme d, different acid - catalyzed reactions can occur on the acidic sites, such as isomerization, oligomerization, cyclization, aromatization and cracking. Cyclization and aromatization take place through hydrogen transfer reactions, while cracking generally tak es place through Œ≤ -splitting reactions. These cracking reactions can occur randomly in the polymer structure or preferably at the end of the chain. The occurrence of either possibility depends mainly on the acidity and pore structure of the chosen catalyst (SERRANO et al., 2012).
Figure 8: Characterization of pyrolysis oil in the absence and presence of Catalyst 1.

In pyrolysis teste, the carbon distribution range was also analyzed. I t was observed that the presence of the catalyst directed towards lighter fractions, in the range from C1 to C12, as shown in Table 5. The increase in the naphtha corresponding fraction could be used by the petrochemical industry. However, the naphtha obta ined with Catalyst 1 was very olefinic and aromatic, different from that used by petrochemicals. To maximize a paraffinic naphtha, a catalyst with larger pores than the catalyst containing zeolite Y is recommended, as it will allow a greater part of the po lymer chain to enter the pores and break down into fractions that are not so favorable for the formation of aromatics. Also, larger pore size increases hydrogen transfer reactions, forming more paraffins. Finally, it is highlighted that mesopores can also bring improvements in the development of a catalyst for such application, since, as shown in the TGA, accessibility is an important factor for catalysts in polymer cracking. Another component that can be added in a better catalyst formulation is the use of alumina, which can aid in pre - cracking the charge.

CONCLUSION Catalysts were characterized by XRD, XRF, BET, Acidity and TGA. In the thermogravimetric analysis was possible to verify the effect of the catalysts at the beginning of the reaction. It also indicated that accessibility plays an important role in catalyst activity, often compensating fo r the lower acidity of some materials. Finally, in the pyrolysis tests it was possible to observe that in the absence of the catalyst, the effect of temperature on the quantities of products was noticed, but there was little effect on the composition. A po sitive effect of the use of commercial catalyst 1 was also observed, which directed the heavy liquid products (waxes) to lighter fractions in the range of C1 -C12. Furthermore, the catalyst directed the products to isoparaffins and aromatics, according to t he mechanism via carbocations of catalytic cracking.
